title-group.article-title: An elastoplastic damage-induced anisotropic constitutive model at finite strains

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
2Institute for Nano-Science and Technology, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: R Naghdabadi, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Institute for Nano-Science and Technology, Sharif University of Technology, 11155-9567 Tehran, Iran. Email: naghdabd@sharif.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper, a hyperelastic plastic damage-induced anisotropic constitutive model is proposed based on the logarithmic strain in finite deformations. The evolution equations are written in terms of the material time derivative of the stress tensor conjugate to the logarithmic strain. The dissipation inequality is considered in the intermediate configuration with some appropriate internal variables. The Helmholtz free energy is considered as combination of three parts including elastic, plastic and damage. The exponential isotropic plasticity hardening and linear isotropic damage hardening are considered. For taking into account the unilateral effect in the damage growing, a modified stress tensor is considered. A return mapping two-step operator split algorithm, elastic predictor and plastic-damage corrector, is adopted for the integration of the evolution equations. To present some numerical results, the proposed constitutive model has been implemented into a finite element implicit code. For validating the model and also showing its capabilities, several benchmark examples are solved. In these examples, the deterioration in the material properties due to the propagation of the damage is well simulated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Growing of damage as a consequence of evolution of internal micro-defects in materials leads to degradation of mechanical properties up to the complete failure. Continuum damage mechanics (CDM) is the most popular inelastic theory which is concerned with the effective continuum representation of a material including distributed micro-defects (micro-cracks and micro-voids). To describe the deterioration of material properties within the framework of continuum thermodynamics, several continuum damage models have been developed. The concept of effective stress in the damaged materials was initially introduced by Kachanov (1958). Recently, CDM has been widely used in different manifests including brittle damage (Abu Al-Rub and Kim, 2010; Cicekli et al., 2007; Ganjiani et al., 2011; Lubarda and Krajcinovic, 1995; Lubarda et al., 1994; Voyiadjis et al., 2008, 2009; Wu et al., 2010a, 2010b), ductile damage (Brünig, 2006; Chow and Lu, 1992; Chow and Wang, 1988a; Chow et al., 2001; Hayakawa and Murakami, 1997, 1998; Wang and Chow, 1989) and creep damage (Rodin, 2000). The phenomenological approach of CDM involves a set of internal variables motivated by experimental observations which are consistent with the principles of irreversible thermodynamics. An important issue in formulating a constitutive damage model is the appropriate choice of the mathematical forms for the damage variables. In order to formulate the constitutive damage model, the concept of effective stress can be used in the framework of strain equivalence principle (Chow and Wang, 1987a, 1987b; Olsson and Ristinmaa, 2005) or energy equivalence principle (Grammenoudis et al., 2009a, 2009b; Ju, 1989; Lee et al., 1997; Olsson and Ristinmaa, 2005; Voyiadjis et al., 2009).

On the micro-scale, the movement of material elements may be caused by several phenomena like slip of dislocations up to failure, internal deterioration due to growth of damage and/or sliding of grain boundaries. Within the concept of continuum theory micro-defects are homogenized into the phenomenological descriptions. When the dominant deformation mechanism is the slip of dislocations, plasticity theory can well simulate the deformation. In this theory, the deterioration of material properties due to growth of damage is neglected. In order to study the damage effects, CDM is a powerful theory which can describe the deterioration of materials in macro-scale due to initiation and growth of micro-voids or micro-cracks. In general, the damage growth may occur in both elastic and plastic deformations. Generally, there is a coupling between the elastoplastic behavior and the damage status. Various types of phenomenological damage theories related to plasticity theory describe the deterioration of materials in the infinitesimal deformation (e.g., Abu Al-Rub and Voyiadjis, 2003; Brünig, 2006; Chow and Wang, 1987b, 1988b; Hansen and Schreyer, 1994; Hayakawa and Murakami, 1997, 1998; Ju, 1989; Simo and Ju, 1987a, 1987b; Voyiadjis et al., 2009). From the computational perspective, the coupling must preserve the basic rules in the plasticity theory such as convexity of the yield surface. On the other hand, some models treat the damage as an internal variable, with its evolution similar to the plasticity theory. In these models, the damage evolution is governed by the definition of a damage yield surface. The existence of a damage yield surface in addition to the plastic yield surface as well as damage evolution equations causes some complexity in numerical procedures for simulating the practical cases.

Constitutive modeling of elastoplastic materials in the finite deformations has received considerable attention over the last years. Generally, the extension of an infinitesimal theory to the finite strain theory is not straightforward. The earliest constitutive models used in the finite deformation were based on the additive decomposition of the strain tensor into the elastic and plastic parts. Based on the multiplicative decomposition of the deformation gradient into the elastic and plastic parts, the motion of the body from the initial configuration to the stress-free or intermediate configuration is described by the plastic part of the deformation gradient, and the motion from this configuration to the current state is given by the elastic part. For treating with the elastic part of the deformation, the hyperelastic behavior of the material is assumed by many researchers (Simo, 1988; Simo and Miehe, 1992). In the work done by Weber and Anand (1990), a constitutive model was developed using Hencky or logarithmic strain for isotropic hyperelastic viscoplastic materials. A great advantage of the hyperelastic assumption is that it avoids unphysical energy dissipation during elastic cyclic (Kojic and Bathe, 1987). The strain-energy function in isotropic elasticity is in good agreement with experiments for a wide class of materials in moderate strains when the infinitesimal measure of the strain is replaced with the logarithmic strain (Caminero et al., 2011; Cuitino and Ortiz, 1993; Eterovic and Bathe, 1990; Moran et al., 1990; Peric et al., 1992; Simo, 1992).

In the aspect of presentation of an elastoplastic damage constitutive model in the framework of finite strains, Ju (1989) proposed a damage-elastoplasticity theory based on the effective stress concept, hypothesis of strain equivalence and the multiplicative split of deformation gradient. Lubarda (1994) formulated an extension of the elastoplastic constitutive model for analysis of elastically isotropic materials based on the multiplicative decomposition of the deformation gradient for the materials whose elastic properties change during the deformation as a result of the material degradation and the corresponding damage. In his work, the total strain rate is decomposed into elastic, damage and plastic parts. De Souza Neto et al. (1993; De Souza Neto and Peric, 1996) extended the theory described by Eterovic and Bathe (1990) to formulate the Lemaitre scalar damage model in finite deformations based on an additive split of the logarithmic strain rate into elastic and plastic contributions. They performed the numerical integration of the constitutive equations by an algorithm which is similar to the standard return mapping procedure used in the infinitesimal theory. In addition, Steinmann et al. (1994) formulated two well-known isotropic damage models, i.e. the Lemaitre and Gurson models, in the framework of finite multiplicative elastoplasticity based on the logarithmic Hencky strain. In their work, the remarkable influence of damage on the behavior of the material, especially within necking and localization computations, has been emphasized.

Lin and Brocks (2006) extended a Chaboche-type infinitesimal viscoplastic theory to the finite strain coupled with anisotropic damage in order to describe the creep responses of different high-temperature materials as well as to predict the location of creep damage in the materials. Soyarslan and Tekkaya (2010) presented an orthotropic finite plasticity model coupled with a Lemaitre-type isotropic ductile damage based on the logarithmic strain and its conjugate stress measure.

Mahnken (2000) proposed a modification of finite elastoplastic model described by Miehe (1994) to develop an elastoplastic-damage model formulated in the plastic intermediate configuration. The elastic response is written in terms of the elastic logarithmic strain, where the total (deviatoric and isochoric) elastic part of the free energy is considered to be coupled with the damage. This coupling is regarded as an extension of the formulation of Steinmann et al. (1994), where only the elastic isochoric part of the free energy is considered to be coupled with the damage. Also, Lin and Schomburg (2003) presented a formulation and its numerical implementation of an isotropic finite elastic-viscoelastic-elastoplastic constitutive law with isotropic damage for describing filled rubber-like materials.

The propagation of damage in material causes some deterioration in the material properties. Due to the damage propagation, we treat with the anisotropic behavior in the material. Actually, this type of anisotropy is developed as the loading is applied. In some applications such as metal forming, rolling, deep drawing, crush testing etc, the existence of large deformations necessitate developing a finite deformation model which also captures the damage evolution. Computational large strain plasticity is now well established for the case of isotropic elastoplasticity. On the other hand, the development of an anisotropic elastoplastic model at finite strains is a difficult task.

When the damage is scalar, the elastic behavior of an initially isotropic material remains still isotropic, and the stress and strain tensors are commutative. In this case, the procedure of Eterovic and Bathe (1990) for finite strain can be used for moderate elastic strains. But in the cases of elastic anisotropy, some difficulties arise in the implementation of the algorithms. Montáns and Bathe (2007) modeled large strain anisotropic elastoplastic materials using the logarithmic strain. In that contribution and also in Kim et al. (2009), they studied the effect of plastic spin on the change of the anisotropy directions. Subsequently, Caminero et al. (2011) presented a model for large strain anisotropic elastoplastic in which the elastic anisotropy is also taken into account and the effect of plastic spin is neglected. Their formulation has been developed using the hyperelastic model in terms of logarithmic strain and the multiplicative decomposition of the deformation gradient is used. They used the same large strain isotropic elastoplastic algorithms in the numerical procedure. They presented the computational algorithm using a standard small strain procedure in which the stress is interpreted as the generalized Kirchhoff stress and the strain as the logarithmic strain. In formulating the anisotropic elastoplastic model in the framework of finite strain, similar works have been published in the literature, e.g. Bruhns and Bongmba (2001) and Kim et al. (2009). Menzel et al. (2005) developed a formulation of finite anisotropic viscoplasticity coupled with anisotropic continuum damage that accounted for anisotropic degradation and for kinematic as well as proportional hardening. In their work, they neglected the effect of plastic spin.

In this paper, an elastoplastic constitutive model coupled with the anisotropic damage in finite deformations is proposed. The elastic behavior of the material is assumed to be hyperelastic and it is described based on the logarithmic strain. The multiplicative decomposition of the deformation gradient into the elastic and plastic parts is also considered. In the framework of irreversible thermodynamics, the dissipation inequality in the intermediate configuration is written. The evolution equations are described in terms of the material time derivative of the stress tensor conjugate to the logarithmic strain. To take into account the unilateral effect of the damage, a modified stress tensor is considered. After developing the model mathematically, an algorithm for integration of the constitutive equations is also presented. For this purpose, a return mapping two-step operator split algorithm, the elastic predictor and plastic-damage corrector are used. The numerical integration is performed in the intermediate configuration. Utilizing a user-defined subroutine UMAT in the finite element program ABAQUS/Standard, several benchmark examples are presented for validating as well as investigating the capabilities of the proposed model.

sec.title: Preliminaries
sec.p: The deformation gradient tensor is defined as: (1)F=∂x∂X where x and X denote positions of a particle in the current and reference configurations, respectively. The polar decomposition of the deformation gradient can be written as: (2)F=RU where U is the total right stretch tensor and R is the total rotation. To characterize the finite strain elastoplastic deformation of a body, we adopt the multiplicative decomposition of the deformation gradient into an elastic Fe and a plastic part Fp as: (3)F=FeFp Equation (3) implies the existence of a stress-free (released) plastic intermediate configuration. The plastic deformation gradient Fp corresponds to the deformation from the initial to the intermediate configuration while the elastic deformation gradient Fe is conceptually obtained by unloading from the current configuration to a state of zero stress in such a way that no inelastic process takes place during the deformation. The velocity gradient l=F·F-1 in the current configuration can be decomposed into elastic le and plastic lp parts as: (4)l=le+lp=F·e(Fe)-1+Fe[F·p(Fp)-1](Fe)-1 We can define the velocity gradient in the intermediate configuration L~ by pull-backing of l to the intermediate configuration as: (5)L~=FeTlFe Substituting equations (4) into (5), the following expression is obtained: (6)L~=FeTF·e+FeTFe[F·p(Fp)-1]=FeTF·e+CeL~p where Ce=FeTFe is the right Cauchy-Green tensor in the intermediate configuration. The term F·p(Fp)-1 in equation (4) is defined as plastic velocity gradient in the intermediate configuration: (7)L~p=F·p(Fp)-1 or (8)F·p=L~pFp Equation (7) can be decomposed into the symmetric D~p and skew W~p parts as follows: (9)L~p=D~p+W~p with (10)D~p=12[F·p(Fp)-1+(Fp)-TF·pT], W~p=12[F·p(Fp)-1-(Fp)-TF·pT] Analogous to the decomposition (9), the term FeTF·e in equation (6) can be decomposed into the symmetric (•)s and skew (•)w parts: (11)(FeTF·e)s=12[FeTF·e+F·eTFe], (FeTF·e)w=12[FeTF·e-F·eTFe] Since the plastic deformation is assumed to be isochoric, we have Jp=det(Fp)=1. Therefore, as det(F)>0, it follows from equations (3) that Je=det(Fe)>0. It assures the polar decomposition of the elastic deformation gradient tensor (c.f. De Souza Neto et al., 1993), and it can be written as (12)Fe=ReUe where Ue is a positive definite symmetric tensor known as the elastic right stretch tensor. Also, the orthogonal tensor Re is identified as the elastic rotation. The elastic right Cauchy-Green deformation tensor Ce and the logarithmic strain measure (Hencky strain) He are related to Ue as: (13)He=12ln(Ce)=ln(Ue) Adopting the spectral representation of the right Cauchy-Green deformation tensor, we write: (14)Ce=∑i=13λie2Ni⊗Ni where λie (i=1,2,3) are principal elastic stretches and Ni are the corresponding eigenvectors. Therefore, the logarithmic strain is written as: (15)ln(Ue)=∑i=13ln(λie)Ni⊗Ni Effective stress is the basic hypothesis in most isotropic and anisotropic models of CDM, in which the damage can be viewed as a macroscopic state variable with effects on the average microscopic damage growth. However, the details of microscopic damage growth are usually neglected. For this purpose, the effective Cauchy stress tensor σ¯ is defined by applying a fourth-order “damage effect” tensor, M, to the nominal Cauchy stress tensor σ via: (16)σ¯=M(ℜD):σ where ℜD is the second-order damage tensor in the current configuration. In this work, a diagonal tensor analogous to the definition of Lu and Chow (1990) is adopted for M(ℜD) to derive the constitutive equations of the elastoplastic-damage model. The damage is presented by diagonal matrix with the principal values ℜDi, corresponding to the material degradation in each principal directions, with 0≤ℜDi≤1. The case ℜDi=0 corresponds to the no damage condition, while ℜDi=1, in theory, corresponds to a fully damaged condition.

The elastic strain energy is written here based on the logarithmic elastic strain tensor He as (Caminero et al., 2011): (17)Ψe=12HeT:Ce:He where the elastic stiffness tensor Ce may be an anisotropic tensor. Analogous to the hypothesis of elastic energy equivalence, we can write (Chow and Wang, 1987b; Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2006). (18)C¯e=M~T(D):Ce:M~(D) where D and M~(D) are the damage and damage effect tensors in the intermediate configuration. Parameter Ce denotes the fourth-order damaged elastic stiffness tensor and also C¯e the undamaged (effective) elastic stiffness tensor, which is considered here as: (19)C¯e=2μI+λI⊗I with I and I as the fourth-order and second-order identity tensors, and μ, λ as the Lamé constants. The relation between the logarithmic strain tensor He and its effective one H¯e is: (20)He=M~(D):H¯e Similarly, the following relation exists between the spatial logarithmic strain tensor he and its effective one h¯e: (21)he=M(ℜD):h¯e Now, using the relations He=ReTheRe (Holzapfel, 2002) and H¯e=ReTh¯eRe then doing some mathematical manipulations, the damage tensor in the intermediate configuration is obtained via the push-forward operation by ReT as follows: (22)D=ReTℜDRe When there is no damage in the material, the damage effect tensor is identity and therefore we have Ce=C¯e. As the damage grows, the damage effect tensor induces anisotropy in the material, i.e. Ce in contrast to C¯e will be a mathematically anisotropic fourth-order tensor.

The stress power in the intermediate configuration can be expressed as: (23)Pint=S~:L~=S~:(FeTF·e+CeL~p)=S~:(FeTF·e)s+S~:Ce(D~p+W~p) where the S~ is the second Piola-Kirchhoff stress tensor in the intermediate configuration, noting that in the case of anisotropic elasticity, S~ is not the pull-back of the rotated Kirchhoff stress tensor τR=ReTτRe. Since S~ is symmetric, we have S~:(FeTF·e)w=0 and therefore equation (23) can be rewritten as: (24)Pint=S~:(FeTF·e)s+CeS~:(D~p+W~p) where Σ~=CeS~ is called the Mandel stress tensor. By decomposition of the Mandel stress into a symmetric part Σ~s=12(CeS~+S~Ce) and a skew part Σ~w=12(CeS~-S~Ce), the stress power in equation (24) can be written as: (25)Pint=S~:(FeTF·e)s+(Σ~s+Σ~w):(D~p+W~p) (26)=S~:(FeTF·e)s+Σ~s:D~p+Σ~w:W~p Let us define the stress tensor T as the conjugate to He. Thus, in view of (17) we can write: (27)T=∂Ψe∂He=Ce:He where T is named as the logarithmic stress tensor. For moderate elastic strains and elastic anisotropy, the following relations can be considered (Caminero et al., 2011): (28)Σ~s≈T and (29)Σ~=Σ~s+Σ~w≈T+Tw in which Tw is a measure due to the lack of commutative property between He and T: (30)Tw=HeT-THe When He and T have the same eigenvectors (as what we have in the case of isotropic elasticity), Tw is zero. In this case, the eigenvectors of S~ and Ce are coincident and hence these two tensors commute. Therefore, Tw=Σ~w=0 and for the symmetric part of the Mandel stress tensor we can write: (31)Σ~s=12(CeS~+S~Ce)=UeS~Ue=ReTτRe=τR=T Noting that the polar decomposition of the elastic deformation tensor Fe=ReUe has been used. In equation (31), τR is the rotated Kirchhoff stress tensor which is obtained by rotation of Kirchhoff stress tensor τ into the intermediate configuration. In the isotropic elasticity, the rotated Kirchhoff stress tensor τR is conjugate to the logarithmic strain tensor while this conjugacy relation is not valid in the anisotropic elasticity.

sec.title: Dissipation inequality
sec.p: As an extension of the Helmholtz free energy to the finite deformations, it is assumed that this energy Ψ can be decomposed into several independent parts: elastic energy Ψe as a function of the logarithmic strain tensor He and the damage tensor D, the energy associated with the plastic flow Ψp and the energy associated with the damage Ψd. An expression for the total Helmholtz free energy can be written as: (32)Ψ(He,D,r,β)=Ψe(He,D)+Ψp(r)+Ψd(β) where r is an accumulated plastic strain and β is the overall damage parameter. Also, Ψp represents the effects of the isotropic hardening of plastic deformation, while Ψd is a parameter which characterizes the isotropic hardening in damage process. According to the energy equivalence hypothesis, the elastic Helmholtz free energy Ψe(He,D) can be written as: (33)Ψe(He,D)=12H¯eT:C¯e:H¯e=12HeT:M~-T:C¯e:M~-1:He

This function has a good correlation with experimental observations in the range of moderate elastic strains. Also, we have: (34)Ψp(r)=R∞[r+1bexp(-br)] (35)Ψd(β)=12Kdβ2 where R∞, b and Kd are material constants. The combination of the first and second laws of thermodynamics yields the developed Clausius-Duhem inequality in the intermediate configuration as: (36)E·=Pint-Ψ·=Pint-Ψ·e-Ψ·p-Ψ·d≥0 Whereas the elastic response is anisotropic, the principal directions of T and He are not coincident; therefore, they do not commute. By assuming that the anisotropy directions are permanent (Montáns and Bathe, 2007), the rate of elastic part of the free energy Ψ·e can be written as: (37)Ψ·e=T:H·e
Remark
In the isotropic materials, the elastic strain and work-conjugate stress measure commute and thus, the plastic spin W~p vanishes. In anisotropic materials, the effects of plastic spin W~p arise in the lack of commutation between elastic strain and its work-conjugate stress measure. The rotations of the elastic and plastic anisotropy directions during loading can be referred as a consequence of the plastic spin. As mentioned by Han et al. (2003) and Montáns and Bathe (2007) and experimentally observed by Bunge and Nielsen (1997) and Truong Qui and Lippmann (2001), the effect of rotation of the anisotropy directions and the plastic spin is negligible for aluminium in moderate strains. In this paper, we neglect the constitutive equation capturing the effect of plastic spin W~p. This assumption makes the constitutive equations and numerical algorithm easy to understand. It is important to note that neglecting the plastic spin does not result in the loss of generality of the present constitutive equations for materials in which anisotropy directions have small rotations under loading.
The plastic dissipation inequality can be written as follows (for more details see Caminero et al., 2011; Montáns and Bathe, 2007) (38)E·p=Σ~s:D~p-∂Ψe∂D:D·-∂Ψp∂rr·-∂Ψd∂ββ·≥0
The thermodynamic force Y conjugate to damage D is often referred to as the “damage energy release rate”. Following the rules of thermodynamics of irreversible processes, this parameter is written as (39)YT≡∂Ψe∂D=H¯eT:C¯e:∂H¯e∂D
Based on the equivalence of elastic energy hypothesis, for the effective logarithmic stress tensor T¯ we have: (40)T¯=M~(D):T=C¯e:H¯e
Using equation (40), equation (39) is rewritten as: (41)YT=T¯T:C¯e-1:∂T¯∂D=TT:M~T:C¯e-1:X with (42)X=∂T¯∂D=∂M~(D)∂D:T
The thermodynamic force Y is regarded as the damaging driving-force and is understood to control the evolution of the damage. This definition is analogous to the definition of “fracture energy release rate” commonly used in the theories of fracture mechanics. It is convenient to introduce the plastic hardening threshold R and the damage strengthening threshold B as the thermodynamic forces associated with r and β, respectively. So, from equation (38) we have: (43)R≡∂Ψp∂r=R∞[1-exp(-br)] (44)B≡∂Ψd∂β=Kdβ
Using the hypothesis of normal dissipativity for the plastic flow rule as well as the evolution equations for the internal variables we can write: (45)D~p=ζ·p∂Fp∂Σ~s=ζ·p∂Fp∂T, r·=-ζ·p∂Fp∂R, D·=ζ·d∂Fd∂Y, β·=-ζ·d∂Fd∂B in which the relation Σ~s≈T has been used. In equation (45), ζ·p and ζ·d are the positive plastic and damage multipliers. Also, Fp and Fd are the plastic and damage dissipation potentials, respectively.

sec.title: Plastic dissipation potential
sec.p: For the plastic dissipation potential (plastic yield surface), the following relation is adopted: (46)Fp(T,R;D,r)=Teq-[R0+R(r)] where R0 is the initial strain hardening threshold and the effective equivalent stress Teq is defined as: (47)Teq={12T¯T:H:T¯}12={12TT:H¯:T}12 with H¯ as the effective plastic characteristic tensor given by: (48)H¯=M~T(D):H:M~(D)

The positive definite tensor H for orthotropic materials is represented by a 6 × 6 matrix in the material principal coordinate system as: (49)H=[G+H-H-G000-HH+F-F000-G-FF+G000000N000000L000000M] where F, G, H, N, L, M are parameters characterizing the current state of plastic anisotropy. Let us assume an associated type flow rule; i.e. the yield surface is assumed to be identical with the plastic dissipation potential Fp(T,R;D). The yield function in equation (46) furnishes the constitutive equation for plastic strain increment D~p and the increment of isotropic hardening variable r· as follows: (50)D~p=ζ·p∂Fp∂T=ζ·pNp (51)r·=-ζ·p∂Fp∂R=ζ·p where Np is a unit vector normal to the plastic yield surface which can be written as: (52)Np=H¯:T2Teq=M~T:H:M~:T2Teq The plastic yield surface, equation (46), should also satisfy the following Kuhn-Tucker loading/unloading conditions: (53)Fp≤0, ζ·p≥0, ζ·pFp=0

sec.title: Damage dissipation potential
sec.p: Assuming that the material axes of orthotropy coincides with the principal axes of stress, a damage criterion, in the form of a quadratic homogeneous convex function of damage release rate Y, offers a convenient way to model the orthotropic damage evolution: (54)Fd(Y,B;D,β)=Yeq-[B0+B(β)] (55)Yeq={12YT:J:Y}12 where J is a second-order damage characteristic tensor describing the damage induced change in the damage surface. The symbol B0 in equation (54) is a material constant which specifies the size of the initial damage surface. The threshold B(β) is interpreted as the maximum value that Yeq has reached during the deformation history (with the initial value B0), representing a damaging hardening material. Similar to the definition of plastic flow, the evolution law for anisotropic damage is written as: (56)D·=ζ·d∂Fd∂Y=ζ·dNd (57)β·=-ζ·d∂Fd∂B=ζ·d where Nd is a unit vector normal to the damage surface describing the direction of damage propagation which is written as: (58)Nd=J:Y2Yeq In the same way to the plasticity case, the following Kuhn-Tucker loading/unloading conditions control the damage evolution: (59)Fd≤0, ζ·d≥0, ζ·dFd=0

The damage characteristic tensor J has been extensively discussed in the literature and many formulations have been suggested (Bielski et al., 2006). In this work, a symmetric damage characteristic tensor J of the second-order is used (Chow and Wang, 1988b; Zhu and Cescotto, 1995). The characteristic tensor J on the 3 × 3 matrix format is written as: (60)J=2[1μμμ1μμμ1] where μ≥0 is a material constant. The parameter μ relates the evolutions of D·2 or D·3 to D·1. For clarity, the proposed constitutive model mentioned in the previous sections is summarized in Box 1.
Box 1. Summary of the constitutive relations for the proposed elastoplastic damage model.
Multiple decomposition of the deformation gradient
F=FeFp
Stress and strain measures:
He=ln(Ue)=(1/2)ln(FeTFe)
T=M~-1:C¯e:M~-1:He
Σ~s=T
Σ~=T+HeT-THe
Evolution equations:
D~p=ζ·pNp
r·=ζ·p
D·=ζ·dNd
β=ζ·d
Np=(M~T:H:M~:T)/(2Teq)
Nd=(J:Y)/(2Yeq)
Y=XT:C¯e-1:M~:T
Yield surfaces:
Fp(T,R;D,r)={1/2TT:H¯:T}1/2-[R0+R(r)]
Fd(Y,B;D,β)={1/2YT:J:Y}1/2-[B0+B(β)]
Loading/unloading conditions
Fp≤0,ζ·p≥0,ζ·pFp=0
Fd≤0,ζ·d≥0,ζ·dFd=0

sec.title: Unilateral (closure) effect
sec.p: In the compressive stress state, the mechanism of damage propagation is different with that of the tension. The spectral decomposition is a typical technique to simulate the closure (unilateral) effect in the tension or compression loadings. Chaboche (1992) discussed the unilateral effect of damage for different models and concluded that when the unilateral condition is applied, these models either have a non-realistic discontinuity in the stress–strain response or in some loading states the unacceptably non-symmetric elastic stiffness is detected. To account for micro-crack opening/closure effect in damaged materials, this technique can be applied to the strain tensor (Hansen and Schreyer, 1994) or the stress tensor (Bielski et al., 2006; Hayakawa and Murakami, 1998; Zhu and Cescotto, 1995). In this paper, for describing the micro-crack closure effect, the spectral decomposition of the stress tensor is adopted. In this regard, we have (61)T*=∑i=13Ti*ni⊗ni=∑i=13ξ(Ti)Tini⊗ni, |ni|=1 where Ti* is the principal values of T* defined as the weighted stress tensor in direction i, and ni is the ith corresponding unit principal direction. The weighted stress tensor T*, which represents the closure effect, is given in the principal stress coordinate system as: (62)Ti*=áTiñ-χá-Tiñ≡ξ(Ti)Ti i=1,2,3,no sum. with (63)ξ(Ti)=H(Ti)+χH(-Ti), 0≤χ≤1 where H(•) is the Heaviside step function, á•ñ is McCauley bracket defined by á•ñ=12(•+|•|), and Ti are the principal values of T. The parameter χ is a material constant describing the crack closure effect; χ=1 denotes a complete closure while χ=0 refers to vanishing effects. The regular and tensile spectral projection tensors are defined as: (64)Q=∑i=13ni⊗ei, Q+=∑i=13ξ(Ti)ni⊗ei where ei are the unit vectors with the components {δi1,δi2,δi3}(i = 1, 2, 3) and δij is the Kronecker delta. Therefore, the symmetric tensor P+ can be written as: (65)P+=Q+QT=∑i=13ξ(Ti)ni⊗ni So, we can express the positive part T* as: (66)T*=P+TP+ The fourth-order positive projection tensor P+ can be used in order to write equation (66) as: (67)T*=P+:T with (68)Pijkl+=12(Pik+Pjl++Pil+Pjk+)

sec.title: Implicit integration algorithm
sec.p: In this section, important aspects of the computational implementation and integration procedure used in this work are discussed. The damage-induced anisotropy is taken into account, but it is assumed that the directions of anisotropy in all the configurations do not change. Applying the implicit Euler backward algorithm to equation (8), the discrete form of evolution for the plastic deformation gradient is obtained as: (69)Fn+1p=exp(ΔtD~n+1p)Fnp in which the assumption W~p=0 is used. Using the evolution equation for D~p (equation (50)), equation (69) can be rewritten as: (70)Fn+1p=exp(Δζn+1pNn+1p)Fnp This exponential approximation was also used by Weber and Anand (1990) in the discretization of the plastic flow rule. Pre-multiplication of both sides of the inverted form of equation (69) by the deformation gradient Fn+1 yields: (71)Fn+1e=Fn+1e trialexp(-Δζn+1pNn+1p) where Fn+1e trial, the trial elastic deformation gradient, is: (72)Fn+1e trial=Fn+1Fnp-1 Using equation (71) and defining Cn+1e trial=(Fn+1e trial)TFn+1e trial, we arrive at: (73)Cn+1e trial=exp(Δζn+1pNn+1p)Cn+1eexp(Δζn+1pNn+1p) Expanding equation (73) by Taylor expansion series and using the definition of the logarithmic strain tensor Hn+1e trial=1/2ln(Cn+1e trial) and Hn+1e=1/2ln(Cn+1e), equation (73) leads to the following expression (Caminero et al., 2011; De Souza Neto et al., 1993): (74)Hn+1e=Hn+1e trial-Δζn+1pNn+1p with the constraint ‖Hn+1e trial‖ <<1, i.e. the elastic strains and incremental steps can be moderately large which is satisfied in the metal plasticity. This relation is similar to the additive decomposition of the strain rate, ε·=ε·e+ε·p, adopted in the infinitesimal deformations. In this view, term Δζn+1pNn+1p in equation (74) seems to be the plastic strain increment. Combination of equations (71) and (74) leads to the following relation (De Souza Neto et al., 1993; Eterovic and Bathe, 1990): (75)Rn+1e=Rn+1e trial where Rn+1e trial is the trial elastic rotation. Substituting equation (74) into the elastic law (equation (40)), the following equation for the stress tensor is obtained: (76)Tn+1=M~-T(Dn+1):C¯e:M~-1(Dn+1):(Hn+1e trial-Δζn+1pNn+1p) After making the return mapping algorithm, the configuration is updated and hence the Mandel stress tensor as well as the second Piola-Kirchhoff stress tensor are obtained as: (77)Σ~n+1=Tn+1+Hn+1eTn+1-Tn+1Hn+1e (78)S~n+1=12[(Cn+1e)-1Σ~n+1+Σ~n+1(Cn+1e)-1] Equation (78) assures the symmetry of the second Piola-Kirchhoff stress tensor. At the converged solutions, the Cauchy stress tensor and damage in the current configuration can be obtained as: (79)σn+1=1JFn+1eS~n+1Fn+1eT (80)ℜDn+1=Rn+1eDn+1Rn+1eT In the following section, we present the implicit integration algorithm for the proposed finite strain elastoplastic-damage constitutive model using an implicit backward Euler state update algorithm. Since the algorithm is developed in the intermediate configuration, its mathematical structure is similar to that of the infinitesimal algorithm. Let Fn and Fn+1 are given as the deformation gradient at initial and final time interval [tn,tn+1]. Having entire constitutive state at time tn, i.e. {T,D,Δζp,Δζd}n, the solutions at time tn+1 are obtained by solving the nonlinear constitutive equations using the Newton-Raphson (N-R) iterations. The overall process of finding solutions can be performed using a predictor-corrector scheme. In each loading step, purely elastic relations are first used to calculate a possible solution based on the assumption that the inelastic strains are not evolving. When the plastic and/or damage yielding occurred, the plastic multiplier ζ·p and/or the damage multiplier ζ·d is obtained. At the end of each increment, the stresses and state variables are updated.

sec.title: Elastic predictor
sec.p: The trial parameters can be calculated by assuming that the deformation gradients Fn+1 and Fn are known. In this regard, the trial elastic and plastic parts of deformation gradient as well as the trial logarithmic strain tensor can be obtained as follows: (81)Fn+1p trial=Fnp, Fn+1e trial=Fn+1Fnp-1 (82)Hn+1e trial=12ln(Cn+1e trial)=12ln((Fn+1e trial)TFn+1e trial) The trial damage is defined as the value at the previously converged step, i.e. Dn+1trial=Dn. So, the trial stress tensor Tn+1trial will be (83)Tn+1trial=M~-T(Dn+1trial):C¯e:M~-1(Dn+1trial):Hn+1e trial Consequently, other trial variables can be evaluated as: (84)T¯n+1trial=M~(Dn+1trial):Tn+1trialXn+1trial=X(Tn+1trial,Dn+1trial)Yn+1trial=(Xn+1trial)T:C¯e-1:M~(Dn+1trial):Tn+1trial

With these trial variables, the damage and plastic yield conditions are checked. (85)Fp={12(Tn+1trial)T:M~T(Dn+1trial):H:M~(Dn+1trial):Tn+1trial}12-[R0+R(rn)] (86)Fd={12(Yn+1trial)T:J:Yn+1trial}12-[B0+B(βn)] If Fp≤0 and Fd≤0, the elastic solution is accepted and all trial variables are the solutions, i.e. (•)n+1=(•)n+1trial.

sec.title: Damage corrector
sec.p: This phase is activated when Fp≤0 and Fd>0. In this phase, Δζn+1p=0 and a return-mapping algorithm similar to the small strain theory is adopted to find the unknown variables. The solutions at time tn+1 are obtained by solving the nonlinear constitutive equations through employing the N-R iteration. By setting the damage surface (equations (44) and (54)) to vanish, we can obtain the damage multiplier Δζn+1d as follows: (87)Δζn+1d=1Kd{12Yn+1T:J:Yn+1}12-B0Kd-βn The variables {Tn+1,Dn+1} are calculated using the stress–strain relation and damage evolution equation via N-R iteration. The residual functions used in this N-R method are as follows: (88)RD=Dn+1-Dn-Δζn+1dNn+1d (89)RT=M~T(Dn+1):C¯e-1:M~(Dn+1):Tn+1-Hn+1e trial with (90)Nn+1d=J:Yn+12Yn+1eq As the N-R method converges to the desired tolerance, the damage multiplier can be calculated using equation (87). At the end of this solution, the variables {Tn+1,Dn+1,Δζn+1d} are found. Before updating other variables, the plastic yield condition should be checked, i.e. if the condition Fp(Tn+1,Rn;Dn+1,rn)≤0 is established, the solution is accepted and thus the variables are updated as follows: (91)Hn+1e=Hn+1e trial-Δζn+1pNn+1p, rn+1=rn, βn+1=βn+Δζn+1d Otherwise, the plastic-damage corrector should be applied, as explained in the following.

sec.title: Plastic corrector
sec.p: Similar to the damage corrector, this phase is activated when Fp>0 and Fd≤0. By setting the plastic yield surface (equations (46) and (43)) to vanish, we can obtain the plastic multiplier Δζn+1p as follows (92)Δζn+1p=-1bln[1+R0R∞-1R∞{12Tn+1T:M~T(Dn+1):H:M~(Dn+1):Tn+1}12]-rn In this phase, Δζn+1d=0, Dn+1=Dn and a return-mapping algorithm equivalent to a return-mapping algorithm in the standard elastoplastic problem is adopted to find the variables. The following residual function are used in the N-R method to find the unknown variable Tn+1. (93)RT=M~T(Dn+1):C¯e-1:M~(Dn+1):Tn+1+Δζn+1pNn+1p-Hn+1e trial with (94)Nn+1p=M~T(Dn+1):H:M~(Dn+1):Tn+12Tn+1eq As the N-R method converges to the desired tolerance, the plastic multiplier can be calculated using equation (92). At the end of this algorithm, variables {Tn+1,Δζn+1p} are found. Before updating other variables, the damage yield condition should be checked. If Fd(Yn+1,Bn;Dn,βn)≤0 is established, the solution is accepted and the variables are updated as follows: (95)Hn+1e=Hn+1e trial-Δζn+1pNn+1p, rn+1=rn+Δζn+1p, βn+1=βn Otherwise, the plastic-damage corrector should be applied, as explained in the next section.

sec.title: Plastic-damage corrector
sec.p:
When the conditions Fp>0 and Fd>0 are simultaneously established, the values of plastic multiplier Δζn+1p as well as the damage multiplier Δζn+1d are non-zero. These multipliers can be obtained by setting the plastic and damage surfaces to vanish, i.e. equations (87) and (92). To find the solution, a return-mapping algorithm is applied to the residual equations (88) and (93). As the N-R method converges to the desired tolerance, the plastic and damage multipliers can be calculated using equations (87) and (92). At the end of this solution, the variables {Tn+1,Dn+1,Δζn+1p,Δζn+1d} are found and updating of variables is done as follows: (96)Hn+1e=Hn+1e trial-Δζn+1pNn+1p, rn+1=rn+Δζn+1p, βn+1=βn+Δζn+1d The governing equations for one load step of the N-R iteration are summarized in Box 2.
Box 2. Algorithm for integration of the constitutive equations.
Initialization
Database at the beginning of step: Fn+1, Fn, ℜDn, rn and βn
Elastic predictor
Calculate damage tensor in intermediate configuration Dn
Calculate trial logarithmic strain Hn+1e trial
Evaluate trial stress tensor and other trial variables via equations (83) and (84).
Check damage and plastic yield conditions. If Fp≤0 and Fd≤0, the elastic solution is correct
and set (•)n+1=(•)n+1trial
Damage corrector
If Fp≤0 and Fd>
Set Δζn+1p=0.
Calculate {Tn+1,Dn+1,Δζn+1d}.
If Fp(Tn+1,Rn;Dn+1,rn)≤0, the damage corrector solution is accepted, thus
go to Update the internal variables, else go to Plastic-damage corrector
Plastic corrector
If Fp>0 and Fd≤0
Set Δζn+1d=0 and Dn+1=Dn.
Calculate {Tn+1,Δζn+1p}.
If Fd(Yn+1,Bn;Dn,βn)≤0, the plastic corrector solution is accepted, thus
go to Update the internal variables, else go to Plastic-damage corrector.
Plastic-damage corrector
If Fp>0 and Fd>0
Calculate {Tn+1,Dn+1,Δζn+1p,Δζn+1d}.
Go to Update the internal variables.
Update the internal variables
Hn+1e=Hn+1e trial-Δζn+1pNn+1p,rn+1=rn+Δζn+1p,βn+1=βn+Δζn+1d
Calculate the algorithmic tangent modulus Calg
Calculate the Mandel and the second Piola-Kirchhoff stress tensors
Σ~n+1=Tn+1+Hn+1eTn+1-Tn+1Hn+1e
S~n+1=1/2[(Cn+1e)-1Σ~n+1+Σ~n+1(Cn+1e)-1]
Update the configuration
Un+1e=exp(Hn+1e)
Fn+1e=Fn+1e trialexp(-Δζn+1pNn+1p)
Rn+1e=Fn+1e(Un+1e)-1
Fn+1p=exp(Δζn+1pNn+1p)Fnp
Calculate the Cauchy stress and damage tensors
σn+1=J-1Fn+1eS~n+1Fn+1eT
ℜDn+1=Rn+1eDn+1Rn+1eT

sec.title: Algorithmic tangent modulus
sec.p: At converged values for tn+1, the linearization of the residual equations leads to the following linear system of equations: (97)F,Tp:dTn+1+F,Dp:dDn+1+F,ΔζppdΔζp+F,ΔζdpdΔζd=0F,Td:dTn+1+F,Dd:dDn+1+F,ΔζpddΔζp+F,ΔζdddΔζd=0R,TD:dTn+1+R,DD:dDn+1+R,ΔζpDdΔζp+R,ΔζdDdΔζd=0R,TT:dTn+1+R,DT:dDn+1+R,ΔζpTdΔζp+R,ΔζdTdΔζd=dHn+1e trial where subscript following the comma denotes the partial differentiation with respect to that quantity. These derivatives are obtained as follows (note that for simplicity we drop the index n+1): (98)F,Tp=12Teq{TT:M~T:H:M~}, F,Dp=12Teq{TT:M~T:H:X}, F,Δζpp=-∂R(r)∂Δζp, F,Δζdp=0 (99)F,Td=12Yeq{J:∂Y∂T}, F,Dd=12Yeq{J:∂Y∂D}, F,Δζpd=0, F,Δζdd=-∂B(β)∂Δζd (100)R,TD=-Δζd∂Nd∂T, R,DD=I-Δζd∂Nd∂D, R,ΔζpD=0, R,ΔζdD=-Nd (101)R,TT=M~T:C¯e-1:M~+Δζp∂Np∂T, R,DT=2M~T:C¯e-1:X+Δζp∂Np∂D, R,ΔζpT=Np, R,ΔζdT=0 Solving this system of equations, we can express dTn+1 in terms of dHn+1e trial as: (102)dTn+1=C~alg:dHn+1e trial The algorithmic tangent modulus in the spatial configuration can be obtained by the push-forward operation: (103)Cijklalg=RiaeRjbeRckeRdleC~abcdalg The fourth-order algorithmic tangent modulus Calg which is consistent to the proposed constitutive model preserves the quadratic convergence of the N–R iteration.

sec.title: Numerical results and discussions
sec.p: The proposed constitutive model has been implemented as a user-defined subroutine UMAT in the finite element program ABAQUS/Standard. In this section, we solve some boundary value problems as case studies in order to illustrate the capabilities of the proposed model as well as the effectiveness of the proposed solution procedure.

sec.title: Uniaxial tension test of aluminum 2024-T3
sec.p:
Consider the uniaxial tension test conducted by Chow and Wang (1987a) on 2024-T3 aluminium alloy. In this example, the presented constitutive model is checked by comparing the prediction of the model with the experimental results. The parameters used for simulation are presented in Table 1. In order to determine the parameters involved in the proposed model, two types of experimental data are needed: the stress–strain and the damage-strain data. The stress–strain data are used for calibrating the plasticity parameters and the damage-strain data are utilized for calibrating the damage parameters. The determination procedure for parameters of the model is explained in the following: Table 1.
The set of simulation parameters used for aluminum 2024-T3.
υ E (GPa) R0 (MPa) R∞ (MPa) b Kd (MPa) B0 (MPa) χ µ
0.33 74.5 345 483 7 77.5 0.2 0.25 0.58

Poison’s ratio is selected as the traditional value for aluminum alloy 2024-T3 equal to 0.33 (also matched by the work of Chow and Wang, 1987b), which is determined from uniaxial tension test of a specimen. The parameters E and R0 which denote the elastic modulus and the yield stress are deduced from experimental data (stress–strain data from uniaxial tension test) of Chow and Wang (1988a) as shown in Figure 1; E=74.5GPa and R0=345MPa. The other parameters R∞ and b are adjusted to achieve the best fitting with the experimental data (stress–strain data from uniaxial tension test) as shown in Figure 1. In determination of the plastic parameters, the damage evolution is assumed to be unaffected. The damage hardening parameter Kd is also determined using a fitting procedure to the damage experimental data of Chow and Wang (1987b) (damage-strain data determined from uniaxial tension test using the elastic modulus degradation method) as shown in Figure 2 by fixing the plastic parameters. Finally, a minor modification including all parameters is desirable for the best fitting of both stress–strain and damage-strain data. The value of μ which is used here as 0.58 was reported by Chow and Wang (1987a). The parameter χ is selected as a traditional value for aluminum alloy as 0.25. Figure 1.
The predicted uniaxial tensile results of aluminum 2024-T3 compared with experimental data (Chow and Wang, 1988a).
Figure 2.
Predicted and experimental (Chow and Wang, 1987a) damage evolution in uniaxial tensile test of aluminum 2024-T3.

In order to obtain a relation for measuring the damage threshold parameter B0, consider a uniaxial tension test with damage ℜD. Thus, the damage energy release rate Y is obtained as follows (Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2005): (104)Y=σ2(1-ℜD)3E in which σ and E denote the Cauchy stress and the elastic modulus, respectively. Before the damage propagation, we have ℜD=β=0 in which β is the accumulated damage parameter. As the damage propagates, the damage surface must be zero. (105)Fd=Y-B0=0 Thus, we have (106)B0=σ2/E

This equation is an auxiliary relation to measure the damage threshold B0 from experiment data. In this regard, σ is the stress in which the damage propagation begins. The predicted results have been compared with the experimental data in Figure 1.

As shown in Figure 1, the results have a better agreement with the experimental data when the damaging effect is considered. The growth of damage has also been compared with the experimental data of Chow and Wang (1987a) in Figure 2. It can be seen that the predicted values for ℜD1 has a good agreement with experimental data. For ℜD2, this agreement is partially acceptable. For axial strain up to 0.15, the predicted results have a good agreement with the experiments. For strains greater than 0.15, the predicted results deviate from experiments. These unexpected results may be due to the definition of J which has been assumed to be constant during the deformation. We know that the values of ℜD2 in uniaxial tension test are dependent on the non-diagonal values of matrix J. The variation of damage versus strain (Figure 2) has the same trend as the stress–strain diagram. It contains a linear part which is related to the damage propagation in the elastic deformation, and also a nonlinear part representing the damage evolution in the plastic deformation. It is observed that the damage has initiated at the elastic region and expanded to the plastic region as loading has been extended.

In Figure 3(a), decreasing in the elastic modulus E due to damage evolution is observed. The variation of the Poisson’s ratio υ due to propagation of damage is also shown in Figure 3(b). It is obvious that the Poisson’s ratio is nearly constant while the decrease in the elastic modulus is noticeable. Figure 3.
Predicted and experimental (Chow and Wang, 1987b) deterioration of mechanical properties in Al 2024-T3 under uniaxial tensile test: (a) elastic modulus and (b) Poisson’s ratio.

sec.title: Necking of a circular bar
sec.p:
A well-known standard benchmark example for verification of a finite strain constitutive model is the necking of a circular bar. For this purpose, a circular bar with radius of 6.413mm and length of 53.334mm subjected to the uniaxial tension is considered. Because of the symmetry, one quarter of the specimen with 480 solid elements is modeled (Figure 4). In order to trigger the necking phenomenon in the central section of the bar, a geometric imperfection (2% radius reduction) is introduced at this section. The material properties listed in Table 1 are adopted for this simulation. The undeformed and deformed configurations after a total axial elongation of 7.5mm are shown in Figure 5. In this figure, the contour of the effective plastic strain and overall damage are shown. As indicated in this figure, the critical point which has the maximum damage value as well as the maximum plastic strain is in the middle of the specimen. This point is marked as “A” in Figure 4. Both the stress–strain and damage-strain curves for this critical point are shown in Figure 6. In this figure, the stress–strain curve without considering the damage evolution is compared with the predictions of the damage-base simulation. As indicated in this figure, the propagation of damage causes the stress–strain curve to shift downward. The force-displacement curves for two cases; “no-damage” and “damage”, are compared in Figure 7. As indicated, when the damage evolution is introduced in the constitutive law, opposite to the no-damage case, the load-displacement curve is significantly decreased. This demonstrates the degradation effect of the material due to propagation of damage. The curve for the reduction in the radius at the necking section versus the total elongation for both damage and no-damage cases are compared in Figure 8. As seen in this figure, the damaging process causes more reduction in the radius and consequently makes early failure in the material. As a conclusion, this example shows the capability of the numerical algorithm in modeling such a benchmark example in finite deformations. Figure 4.
Necking of circular bar; one quarter of the specimen with 480 elements.
Figure 5.
Necking of circular bar; (a) the effective plastic strain and (b) the overall damage distributions in the circular bar subjected to the axial elongation.
Figure 6.
Necking of circular bar; (a) the stress–strain and (b) the damage–strain curves of point “A”.
Figure 7.
The force–displacement curve in no-damage and damage cases for a node on the upper side of the specimen.
Figure 8.
Necking of circular bar; displacement at the section of extreme necking versus total elongation for damage and no-damage cases.

sec.title: Uniaxial tension test with central hole
sec.p:
As another example, we consider the uniaxial tension test on a specimen with a central hole. The initial configuration consisting of 6060 solid elements in one quarter of the specimen are shown in Figure 9. The dimensions of the specimen are chosen according to the standard ASTM A370-03a. The thickness of the specimen as well as the radius of the central hole is 3mm. The material properties of Al2024-T3 (Table 1) are used for this example. The contour of the effective plastic strain and overall damage after a total axial elongation of 1.65mm are depicted in Figure 10. As shown in this figure, the maximum value for the overall damage is observed in the centre of the necking zone. This means that the fracture of specimen is initiated from this point. This point is different from the point of the maximum plastic strain. The curve for the reduction in thickness of the specimen at the necking section versus the total elongation for both damage and no-damage cases are shown in Figure 11. As seen in this figure, the propagation of damage causes more reduction in the thickness of the specimen at necking section. Figure 9.
Uniaxial tension test with central hole; the initial configuration with 6060 elements.
Figure 10.
Uniaxial tension test with central hole; the contour of (a) the effective plastic strain and (b) the overall damage in one quarter of the specimen after 1.65 mm axial elongation.
Figure 11.
Uniaxial tension test with central hole; displacement at the section of extreme necking versus total elongation for damage and no-damage cases.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this work, we have proposed a finite strain Hencky-based damage constitutive model. The details of fully implicit algorithm for the finite element analysis of damage-induced anisotropic elastoplastic solids with exponential isotropic plastic hardening and linear isotropic damage hardening have been presented. The algorithm includes the multiplicative decomposition of the deformation gradient tensor into the elastic and plastic parts, hyperelasticity in terms of the logarithmic strain, a stress tensor conjugated to the logarithmic strain, the anisotropic damage and an exponential mapping for the integration of the plastic strains. The plastic-damage correction has been performed using a procedure similar to that of the small strain method. In the case of a scalar damage, the isotropic elastic is achieved and as should be expected, the procedure covers the isotropic elastoplastic algorithm. The algorithm has been consistently linearized in order to obtain the asymptotic quadratic convergence rate of Newton-Raphson iterations. Finally, by utilizing a user-defined subroutine UMAT in the finite element program ABAQUS/Standard, some benchmark examples for validating the model as well as showing its capabilities have been presented. Using these examples, the important effects of the damage on the material behavior specifically on the failure of the structure are illustrated. These examples show that the propagation of the damage causes the deterioration in the material properties.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
